name: King Charles III England Coast Path: Marsland Mouth to Newquay

ai.summary: A challenging 117.8-km segment of the England Coast Path from Marsland Mouth to Newquay. This hard coastal trek blends rugged cliffs, sandy coves, and sweeping sea views with exposed headlands and long stretches between services. It rewards patient hikers with dramatic scenery but requires strong fitness, careful navigation, and thorough planning.
ai.terrain_summary: Rugged coastal terrain dominated by cliff tops, windswept headlands, shingle beaches, and patches of coastal moorland. Expect steep ascents and descents, uneven paths, and muddy sections after rain, with limited services between settlements. Tides and weather can affect routes, so stay on official paths and watch for unstable ground near cliff edges.
ai.safety_notes: Plan for remote coast: check weather and tide tables before each stage; wear sturdy boots and stay well back from cliff edges; carry a map, compass, and fully charged phone with offline backup; inform someone of your itinerary and expected finish; carry sufficient water and high-energy food; in an emergency call 999.
recommended_gear: Sturdy waterproof hiking boots with good ankle support
Layered clothing (base layer, mid-layer, and a warm layer)
Waterproof and windproof outer layer (jacket and pants)
Navigation tools: map and compass or GPS with offline maps
Fully charged phone with a power bank
Headlamp or flashlight with extra batteries
Water supply (2–3 liters) and high-energy snacks
First-aid kit with blister care and seasalt wipes
Emergency beacon or personal locator (PLB) for remote sections
Lightweight camping gear if planning overnight: bivy/shelter, sleeping bag, mat
Dry bag or protective cases for electronics
ai.best_seasons: Late spring to early autumn (roughly April–October) offers the best daylight, milder weather, and trail conditions. Winter hiking can be hazardous due to high winds, heavy rain, and reduced daylight; always assess conditions before setting out.
